byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens, and Alison Smale from Berlin.
byline.original: By ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

abstract: European negotiators press Greece to accept new economic concessions as part of bailout deal worth tens of billions of euros; many measures under review, including a temporary exit from eurozone, are harsher than those rejected by Greek voters in referendum; some see demands as strategy to force Prime Min Alexis Tsipras from office, though there have been some signs of progress on deal.
lead_paragraph: The mood was tense, with some Greek officials pushing back against some proposals and rifts emerging among the 19 nations using the euro over how far to go in making new demands.

headline.main: Leaders From Eurozone Work Into Morning on Greek Crisis
headline.print_headline: Europe Presses Greece to Agree to New Measures

snippet: The mood was tense, with some Greek officials pushing back against some proposals and rifts emerging among the 19 nations using the euro over how far to go in making new demands.
